title: Introduction to Land-based Rainwater Harvesting - RUVIVAL Toolbox

subtasks: Selecting an appropriate planting technique (e.g., strip-catchment tillage).
Planting rows of uncultivated grass to act as a catchment area.
Alternating rows of cultivated crops with the grass rows.
Constructing contour or key-line barriers perpendicular to the slope.
Building barriers from vegetative material, stones, or soil.
Implementing swales or living terraces as cross-slope systems.
Creating basin systems with closed diamond or square shapes.
Planting food trees at the lowest point of the basin for water collection.
Choosing the right land cover for the catchment area (e.g., cultivated land, roads, settlements).
Constructing hillside systems with barriers to accumulate water for irrigation and groundwater recharge.
Building check dams or sand dams across stream beds to infiltrate water and control erosion.
Diverting ephemeral stream water to low-lying areas for crop growth.

tasks.task: Enhancing agricultural activity through land-based rainwater harvesting.
subtasks: Reducing soil erosion and flood occurrences.
Increasing groundwater recharge to improve water availability.
Mitigating the effects of climate change and mismanagement on water resources.
Supporting food availability by increasing agricultural activity.
